webTitle: High street gloom as big retailers' profits hit by poor Christmas sales

fields.bodyText: A wave of gloom swept over the high street as three of the UK's biggest retailers admitted that profits would be hit by poor Christmas sales. Tesco, Morrisons and Marks & Spencer all blamed heavy discounting, a squeeze on shoppers' spending power and unseasonal autumn weather for falling underlying sales and lower than hoped for profit margins. The barrage of poor figures also highlighted a changing retail world in which shoppers are increasingly purchasing online and buying their groceries in small convenience stores or at discounters such as Aldi or Lidl. IGD, the grocery industry research group, said that 50% of shoppers bought something in a food discounter in December. Sales have gone into reverse at large out of town stores as shoppers increasingly choose to buy little and often close to home, which helps cut down on waste and save petrol. Shares in Morrisons sank nearly 8% to 234p as the Bradford-based chain surprised the City, bringing forward its Christmas trading update and warning profits would be at the bottom end of City forecasts. The update showed a dramatic 5.6% decline in sales at established branches in the crucial six weeks to 5 January. The supermarket blamed a variety of factors for its dire performance, from shoppers choosing to spend more at discounters to its lack of an online grocery service, too few convenience stores and poor IT systems, which left it struggling to fight increasingly sophisticated promotions from rivals. The drop came despite help from food inflation and a 0.5% boost to underlying sales as a result of Morrisons opening its stores on Boxing Day and New Year's Day for the first time. Its chief executive, Dalton Philips, said about half the fall in sales was linked to shoppers choosing to spend more money at discounters' stores than ever before at Christmas. "People are being economically squeezed so they are not trading up and they are splitting their shopping basket among different stores," he said. "They have been buying their confectionery from one store and their wine from another store this year. It's a big shift." Tesco, Britain's biggest supermarket chain, also revealed worse-than-expected Christmas sales, down by 2.4% in the UK, when gains from new space and petrol sales were excluded . "Clearly Christmas was disappointing," said its chief executive, Philip Clarke. The retailer admitted that profits would come in as much as £150m below expectations set only last month after a tough end to the year. Clarke said online and convenience store revenue had risen, but the group's out-of-town superstores had suffered falling sales. He said: "It's tough because the market is tough and consumers are still feeling they don't have as much to spend." He said Tesco had taken action to limit price increases in the past six weeks and hinted that the company's profit margin of 5.2%, previously seen as a line in the sand, might come down. Tesco and Morrisons performed markedly worse than rival Sainsbury's, but all have been battered by the discounters. Andrew Stevens, a retail analyst at Verdict Research, said the poor performance of the major grocers put the strength of Britain's economic recovery in doubt. He added: "The emergence of discounters as a bigger threat than many anticipated has meant the UK's largest grocers have emerged into 2014 with battle scars and nothing much to show for the fight." M&S said it had suffered its 10th quarter of declining like-for-like clothing and homewares sales, and it is now three years since the chain has seen underlying growth in its general merchandise business. It was forced into almost unprecedented discounting on key seasonal items such as knitwear in the week before Christmas. The poor sales came despite chief executive Marc Bolland's efforts to revamp clothing with a new management team, refurbished stores and huge investment in IT and logistics operations. Bolland blamed unusually warm weather in October for the underlying sales fall and improved business in the final weeks before Christmas, helped by big discounts, could not make up the lost ground. He accused other retailers of kicking off a price war in December, forcing M&S to offer discounts of up to 30% on clothing in the week before Christmas Day. Rival Debenhams unveiled a profit warning last week after it discounted aggressively in the runup to Christmas, although clothing and homewares store Next – which refused to join in the price-cutting until Boxing Day – had a strong festive season . Total UK sales rose 1.5%, helped by a 1.6% rise in underlying sales of food, as M&S took a bigger share of the market over the festive season. But even the increase in M&S food sales was less than City analysts had expected. Finance director Alan Stewart said: "Clearly our food business was a winner and had a very strong performance. Market expectations were higher but that was because it was a bit of a surprise that the market as a whole got worse." Analysts said there was a sense of relief that trading hadn't been worse, but still trimmed their profit forecasts by about £20m to an average of £630m – down from £1bn in 2008. The poor Christmas trading figures are not helpful for the bosses of Morrisons, Tesco and M&S who are all under pressure to revive their businesses amid heavy competition in a tough and rapidly changing market. All three yesterday insisted they had the right strategy in place and merely needed more time. Bolland, whose position at the top of M&S has been questioned by some shareholders for several months, said: "We are [heading] in the right direction. It is hard to get there but I take every quarter on the chin if need be because the company needs to go in the direction it is going." But Clive Black, an analyst at Shore Capital, said the retailers could not blame their woes entirely on problems in the market. "I don't buy into the idea that all the factors were outside their control." He pointed to the success of Aldi and Lidl as well as Waitrose, the Co-op and M&S's food over Christmas. Convenience store group Nisa also revealed strong Christmas sales, up 15.3% in December on the previous year. Mike Dennis, an analyst at Cantor, said Tesco's performance was particularly poor given that, 21 months into a £1bn turnaround plan, it had introduced a new price matching promotion, refurbished more than 100 stores and given a high-profile relaunch to its premium food range, Tesco Finest. "Our view is that management still has a lot of explaining to do over the poor relative UK sales performance," he said. "Tesco has been unable to differentiate itself from the competition." webTitle: Aluminium firm Alcoa to pay $384m after guilty plea in US over Bahrain bribes

fields.standfirst: Multinational group agrees settlement in US after admitting offence involving kickbacks to Bahraini officials
fields.body:
A subsidiary of Alcoa, the multinational aluminium group, has pleaded guilty in the US to a bribery offence relating to the payment of kickbacks to Bahraini officials through an unnamed London-based middleman with close ties to Bahrain's royal family.

The Alcoa admission comes less than six weeks after the surprise collapse of the UK trial of Victor Dahdaleh, a London-based consultant who had been under investigation by the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) for four years in relation to the bribery scandal.

Alcoa has agreed to pay $223m (£135m) to the US department of justice (DoJ) in criminal fines and forfeiture following admissions that bribes were paid through a London businessman to Bahraini officials including senior members of the royal family. Lawyers for Dahdaleh declined to comment on Alcoa's plea.

Alcoa also reached a parallel civil settlement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) agreeing to pay $161m in disgorgement, bringing the total cost to the New York-listed group to $384m. Alcoa, which has already paid $85m to Bahraini state-run aluminium firm Alba to settle another civil claim, said it "welcomes the resolution of this legacy legal matter".

Dahdaleh, a British-Canadian national, was accused of paying tens of millions of dollars in bribes to former managers of Alba in return for a cut of contracts worth more than $3bn. Last month counsel for the SFO told a judge at Southwark crown court that the agency no longer intended to pursue the prosecution, in part after a star witness, Bruce Hall – accused of receiving bribes while working for Alba over an eight-year period – significantly changed his evidence.

Hall has already pleaded guilty to a UK conspiracy charge and is expected to be sentenced in March.

The SFO does have powers to bring charges against corporate defendants, but did not do so in the case of Alcoa or its subsidiaries. British prosecutors nevertheless co-operated with their US counterparts in helping secure the guilty plea on Thursday from Alcoa World Alumina.

An SFO spokesman said: "We are aware of the announcement and continue to work with the DoJ."

In contrast with the multimillion-dollar fines and settlements secured by the DoJ and SEC, the SFO's aborted prosecution of Dahdaleh has left the businessman open to pursue a substantial claim for costs against taxpayer funds.

The US acting assistant attorney general Mythili Raman thanked the SFO for its help, adding: "Alcoa World Alumina today admits to its involvement in a corrupt international underworld in which a middleman, secretly held offshore bank accounts, and shell companies were used to funnel bribes to government officials in order to secure business.

"The law does not permit companies to avoid responsibility for foreign corruption by outsourcing bribery to their agents, and, as today's prosecution demonstrates, neither will the Department of Justice."

webTitle: Bookmaker shares hit by PM's comments on fixed-odds machines

fields.standfirst: Shares in William Hill and Labrokes tumble after David Cameron says he will address problem high street betting terminals
fields.body:
More than £400m has been wiped off the market value of William Hill and Ladbrokes after David Cameron said he would address the "problem" of lucrative fixed-odds gambling machines in high street bookies.

Shares in Britain's two biggest betting chains dropped by 7% and 9% respectively on Thursday after the prime minister promised he would "get to grips" with problem gambling.

Cameron said he "absolutely shares the concerns" raised by Ed Miliband over the "epidemic" of fixed-odds betting terminals.

The machines, which have been dubbed the "crack cocaine of gambling" by campaigners, are a major moneyspinner for gambling companies. They account for around £1.6bn of the industry's in-store takings of £3bn, according to research group Mintel.

Labour lost a Commons motion calling for local councils to be given more powers to limit the high stakes fruit machines, but Cameron said the government would make an announcement after the publication of a key report into the issue.

"There are problems with the betting and gambling industry and we need to look at them," Cameron said on Wednesday. "If we work together we can probably sort it out."

Analysts at Barclays downgraded their recommendations on both William Hill and Ladbrokes, warning that the "negative news-flow will weigh on the sector".

"Regulatory change has always been the key driver of sentiment toward the gambling sector," Barclays said in note.

Barclays estimates that Ladbrokes has the greatest dependence on FOBTs. Terminals account for around 40% of the company's earnings, compared with 26% for William Hill before interest and tax, the bank said.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer hopeful about overcoming faltering fashion trend

fields.bodyText: "A big deli selling occasional knickers" will not be Marks & Spencer's advertising slogan next Christmas. But the gag from financial risk management firm Company Watch is a good one. For the umpteenth quarter in a row, M&S's food division bailed out the clothing side. To be precise, it was the 10th consecutive quarter that M&S sales of general merchandise fell on a like-for-like basis – by 2.1% this time. The accompanying plea for patience was also familiar: "Customers responded positively to our refocus on quality and style." OK, but the most positive response came when M&S followed the herd and cut prices. That was why the eight-week Christmas period showed a small like-for-like gain in sales, of 0.5%, but the full 13-week quarter did not. But, scratch the surface and there are reasons for mild optimism for M&S in clothing. The online operation was late to the party by about half a decade but now finally looks to be competitive: general merchandise sales were up 32% in the eight-week period. There was also a small market share gain in womenswear. If the designs really are being retuned to meet customers' tastes (as opposed to those of the fashion press), 2014 holds promise. Meanwhile, the food division runs on rails and the biggest part of M&S's capital spending programme has been completed, allowing cash flow to improve. Chief executive Marc Bolland's hold on his post is probably firmer than at any point in the last 18 months.

webTitle: Euro plummets after ECB warns currency zone may need more support

fields.standfirst: European Central Bank head Mario Draghi says Japanese-style stagnation possible amid high unemployment and falling inflation
fields.body:
The European Central Bank sent the euro tumbling on world markets after it warned that the 18-member currency zone may need further support to prevent a Japanese-style period of stagnation.

The ECB president, Mario Draghi, said persistently high unemployment, falling inflation and difficult lending conditions were harming the recovery, and the ECB stood ready to use all the tools available to maintain confidence and growth.

Speaking as the central bank kept interest rates at 0.25% on Thursday, he said the ECB would consider printing money as well as other measures should there be a further deterioration in the availability of credit or another drop in inflation.

"The governing council strongly emphasises that it will maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy for as long as necessary," he said.

The warning came as the UK economy appeared to be moving strongly in the opposite direction and concerns that it will soon overheat.

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee kept base interest rates steady at 0.5% at its January meeting but an increasing number of analysts called on the Bank's governor, Mark Carney, to prepare for a rate rise as early as the summer.

Carney has signalled his intention to keep rates at ultra-low levels until the recovery is assured, which Threadneedle Street believes will be mid-2015 at the earliest.

But the unexpectedly sharp rise in gross domestic product over the last year and the speed with which employers are adding jobs has convinced many economists that rates should rise earlier.

Recruitment agencies reported that job creation surged in December. Pay rates for new staff also rose at the fastest pace for six years, according to a survey by Markit for the Recruitment & Employment Confederation and KPMG.

The survey data suggested that unemployment will continue to drop sharply, possibly falling through the Bank's 7% unemployment rate threshold in early 2014, and that a return to real wages growth is in sight this year.

Chris Williamson, Markit's chief European economist, said the Bank's forecast for unemployment to fall to 7% late this year already looked out of date. Wage rises, however, remained well below the 2.1% inflation rate, rising at 0.9% a year in November.

Britain's booming economy still remains 2% below its peak and manufacturing, which the government has promoted and is which growing strongly, is 9% below levels in 2008. But over the last year it has outstripped rivals to be one of the fastest growing economies in the developed world.

Draghi said a Japanese-style period of stagnation that brings with it falling prices and a decline in consumer demand has yet to arrive, but the ECB must be ready to play a part in boosting confidence in the financial system and broader eurozone economy.

"Right now, we don't see deflation," he said. "By and large we don't see a deflation in the Japanese sense of the 1990s."

France has become a major worry for eurozone policymakers after figures for December appeared to show it slipping back into recession.

Greece's industrial slump has also deepened and unemployment reached a record high, according to data yesterday, highlighting the ravages of a six-year recession even as the debt-laden economy shows tentative signs of a recovery elsewhere.

The jobless rate rose slightly to a record 27.8% in October while industrial output contracted in November for a fifth consecutive month, by 6.1%.

Nevertheless, Draghi said confidence was gradually returning to the eurozone economy and the central bank's very accommodative monetary policy stance was finally finding its way into the real economy.

He stopped short of saying the eurozone crisis is over. "The recovery is there but it's weak, it's modest and as I said many times, it's fragile, meaning that there are several risks, from financial to economic to geopolitical to political risks, that could undermine easily this recovery," he said.

Britain's booming economy still remains 2% below its peak and manufacturing, which the government has promoted and is which growing strongly, is 9% below levels in 2008. But over the last year it has outstripped rivals to be one of the fastest growing economies in the developed world. Draghi said a Japanese-style period of stagnation that brings with it falling prices and a decline in consumer demand has yet to arrive, but the ECB must be ready to play a part in boosting confidence in the financial system and broader eurozone economy. "Right now, we don't see deflation," he said. "By and large we don't see a deflation in the Japanese sense of the 1990s." France has become a major worry for eurozone policymakers after figures for December appeared to show it slipping back into recession. Greece's industrial slump has also deepened and unemployment reached a record high, according to data yesterday, highlighting the ravages of a six-year recession even as the debt-laden economy shows tentative signs of a recovery elsewhere. The jobless rate rose slightly to a record 27.8% in October while industrial output contracted in November for a fifth consecutive month, by 6.1%. Nevertheless, Draghi said confidence was gradually returning to the eurozone economy and the central bank's very accommodative monetary policy stance was finally finding its way into the real economy. He stopped short of saying the eurozone crisis is over. "The recovery is there but it's weak, it's modest and as I said many times, it's fragile, meaning that there are several risks, from financial to economic to geopolitical to political risks, that could undermine easily this recovery," he said.

webTitle: Draghi warns eurozone crisis isn't over; Christmas gloom for Tesco and Morrisons - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• European Central Bank firmly reiterates guidance on monetary policy 

• Eurozone crisis not over, says Draghi - summary

• Bank of England leaves interest rates unchanged despite recovery

• Bad day for some UK retailers
fields.body:
6.04pm GMT

Closing summary

And that's all until the morning. A reminder of the key points:

• European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi has warned that the eurozone crisis not over, given the weak recovery and record unemployment levels.

Faced with weak inflation, the ECB strengthened its forward guidance, promising "firmly" to keep monetary policy accommodative for as long as needed.

At a sometimes light-hearted press conference, Draghi also warned that inflation will remain below target for at least the next two years and promised to take further action if needed to stimulate the economy. See 3.15pm for a full round-up.

• Earlier the ECB, and the Bank of England, had both decided to leave interest rates unchanged and also not launch any fresh stimulus programmes.

• Some economists believe the BoE will soon have to raise rates, but business leaders say it should stick to its position that the UK economy is too weak.

• Over in France, the audit office head has warned that its national debt is at danger levels

• While in the UK, Morrisons and Tesco have emerged as clear losers from the Christmas trading period. Marks & Spencer reported that clothing sales had tumbled again, but got a better reception from the City.

There's a round-up here. while full coverage of how the news broke at 7am starts here, and there's an explanation of what went wrong here.

• Greece's unemployment rate hit a new record high.

• Ireland's borrowing costs have fallen below the UK's

Goodnight, and thanks for the comments (as ever!). GW

5.40pm GMT

FTSE 100, DAX and CAC all fall

European stock markets have closed, and the big three indices all ended in the red.

In Britain, Morrisons dragged the FTSE 100 index down, while the French market was hit by the warning over its national debt levels (see previous post). 

  • FTSE 100: down 30 points at 6691, -0.45%
  • German DAX: down 76 points at 9421, -0.8%
  • French CAC: down 35 points at 4225, -0.8%
  • Spanish IBEX: down 19 points at 10234, - 0.19%
  • Italian FTSE MIB: up 66 points at 19503, +0.34%

David Madden, market analyst at IG, says Mario Draghi's more serious comments also hit optimism in the City:

Equities drifted lower as Mario Draghi fails to convince the market that he can save the eurozone from sinking into the abyss.....

Mr Draghi tried to reassure the market he has a few cards up his sleeve, but actions speak louder than words.

And we didn't get much action today.

Updated at 6.03pm GMT

5.07pm GMT

French national audit boss: French debt in the danger zone

The head of France's national audit office has added to the growing pressure on Francois Hollande by warning that the country's debt levels are approaching the danger zone.

Didier Migaud said in a speech that the French national debt hit 93.4% of GDP, warning:

"The level that's been reached has put our country in a danger zone.

"Efforts undertaken so far are not sufficient to get out."

 Migaud, president of the independent Cour des Comptes body, also warned that France will face higher borrowing costs when the economic recovery picks up.

Reuters has the full story:

France's national debt stood at 90.2 percent of GDP at the end of 2012. The government expects the debt burden to peak this year at 95.1 percent of GDP.

"What wasn't done in 2011, 2012 and 2013 only adds to the extra distance that will have to be travelled in the coming years," Migaud said. "This extra distance won't be the least demanding - quite the contrary."

Despite the growing debt mountain, French bonds, which are among the most liquid in the world, have found firm demand from investors seeking richer yields than those offered on their low-risk German equivalents.Yet even though France benefits from low borrowing costs, servicing France's debt costs the state about €50bn ($68bn) annually, equivalent to about 2.5% of national output.

Migaud said a one percentage point increase in interest rates would add 2 billion euros to the state's debt service costs in the first year and €15bn in the tenth year afterwards.

Despite record levels of debt, France enjoyed its lowest borrowing costs on record last year with an average interest rate of only 1.54% on its medium and long-term debt issued in 2013.

In its first bond auction of the year, France sold €8.3bn of long-term debt on Thursday, drawing strong investor demand.

President Francois Hollande's Socialist government plans to make savings of €15bn this year with €9bn coming from the central state and 6 billion euros from the social security system.

Migaud said that the priority should be on making savings in social services, describing France as unique among European countries for the deficits its social welfare system has consistently run over the last 20 years.

Worth noting that economists disagree about what stage a national debt becomes unsustainable, especially after errors were found in the well-known research paper by Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff.

Updated at 5.09pm GMT

4.33pm GMT

Morrisons suffers on big day for UK retail

We started the day with unexpectedly bad news from Morrisons, weak sales from Tesco and another quarter of falling clothing sales at M&S.

The day ends with Morrisons leading the FTSE 100 fallers (down almost 8%), M&S topping the risers (+3%) and Tesco down around 1.2%.

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets sums up the day:

The opportunism of Morrisons in trying to slip out its bad news at the same time as Tesco and M&S appears to have backfired spectacularly as its shares got pummelled lower to levels last seen in October 2008. Like for like sales slid 5.6% in the 6 weeks to January and highlighted the catching up this particular food retailer has to do in catching up its peers in the on-line space as well as the smaller convenience stores that seem to be appearing with increasing regularity on our high streets from Tesco and Sainsbury. A price downgrade from Panmure Gordon hasn’t helped its cause either.

Marks and Spencer’s food offering has once again come to its rescue, while its general merchandising operation once again showed a fall in like for like sales, the tenth quarter in a row we’ve seen a decline here. While CEO Mr Bolland appears to have the confidence of a lot of the major shareholders for now, the fact that we are almost three years in to the company’s turnaround plan will raise some major concerns from other shareholders who don’t seem to see any silver lining on this side of the business. Nevertheless the shares have rebounded to the top of the FTSE100 on relief that the numbers weren’t as bad as was feared initially after the heavy discounting seen in the pre-Christmas trading period, and an upgrade to “buy” from Investec.

Tesco continues to get squeezed from above and below by smaller peers like Waitrose and Marks and Spencer in the premier part of the food space, while also feeling the effects from the budget side in the form of Lidl and Aldi. The problem being the number one grocer in the UK is that you find that you have to run that little bit faster simply to stand still and for now it is even struggling to do that, particularly at a time when consumers are much more cash conscious.

4.11pm GMT

Back in the City, the FTSE 100 is on track to close at its lowest level of the year. It's down 31 points, or 0.5%, in late trading, dragged down by Morrison (-8% after its mini profit warning this morning).

3.29pm GMT

ING's Carsten Brzeski says that the European Central Bank has " stepped up its verbal power, stressing its determination to act again" at today's press conference.

He also explains the different stimulus measures which the ECB could take: 

In our view, it looks as if the ECB is trying to build a tailor-made toolbox with different tools for different situations.

In our view, there are three main triggers for further ECB action in the coming months: i) unwarranted money market tightening; ii) a faltering of the recovery; and iii) a stronger euro exchange rate.

Obviously, these three factors would have a deflationary impact on the Eurozone economy. Tackling these three problems would indeed require different instruments: (conditional) liquidity for the money market, funding for lending and/or QE for the economy and a negative deposit rate for the exchange rate (or a combination of all three).

3.15pm GMT

ECB press conference - the key points

Well, that was entertaining. 

European Central Bank watchers sometimes joke about whether good Good Mario or Bad Mario will turn up to the monthly press conference. Occasionally we get Super Mario - notably after the ECB single-handedly calmed the eurozone crisis with his OMT bond-buying programme.

Today we were treated to Merry Mario, joking about the difference between perverse and perverted, and happily declaring that the ECB can't run out of money.

But beyond the levity, the message from the ECB is that inflation is going to lurk below its 2% target for at least the next two years. That's why the central bank has "firmly" reiterated its pledge to keep accommodative monetary policies for some time.

Here's the new guidance (emphasis mine):

 Against this background, the Governing Council strongly emphasises that it will maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy for as long as necessary, which will assist the gradual economic recovery in the euro area.

Accordingly, we firmly reiterate our forward guidance that we continue to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time.

The other key points are Draghi's warning that the eurozone crisis is not over. Here's the key quote:

"I'd be very cautious about saying that, be very, very cautious... The recovery is there but it's weak, it's modest and as I said many times, it's fragile meaning that there are several risks from financial to economic to geopolitical to political risks that could undermine easily this recovery."

And on the weak recovery, he warned:

"The risks surrounding the economic outlook for the euro area continue to be on the downside. Developments in global money and financial market conditions and related uncertainties may have the potential to negatively affect economic conditions."

Other interesting points were Draghi's defence of Germany's trade surplus, arguing that attempting to rein in its exports would not help the rest of Europe.

And his insistence that Europe is not repeating the mistakes that drove Japan into a deflationary spiral.

But while Mario Draghi repeatedly said the ECB was ready to act, he didn't really explain what it might do.

Updated at 3.30pm GMT

2.50pm GMT

Updated at 2.50pm GMT

2.44pm GMT

And finally, a question about whether any governing council members voted for an interest rate cut today.

Draghi replies that the discussions focused on potential risks to the recovery.

2.40pm GMT

Back to serious stuff, with a question about the Asset Quality Review.

Draghi says that these important new stress tests will treat eurozone government debt as risk-free -- as laid out under the Basel rules.

There has been talk that the ECB is worried about those banks who have gorged themselves on their own sovereign debt. 

2.38pm GMT

Draghi on perverse vs perverted

More levity in Frankfurt, after Mario Draghi is asked about his comments last month that Germans have a perverse fear of inflation.

Draghi turns to dictionary corner, joking that "there is a difference between perverse and perverted" (take note, younger readers)

Perverse, he says means "persistent in error, different from what is reasonable".

And Draghi adds that he understands the concerns of savers and hopes they will share in the economic recovery which the ECB is striving for. 

2.31pm GMT

A journalist asks whether the ECB can ever run out of money.

Draghi gives a little chortle, and says that "technically, no....we cannot run out of money".

So we have ample resources for coping with all our emergencies.

2.29pm GMT

Draghi: We see no Japanification

Draghi insists that Europe is not plunging into a Japanese-style deflation crisis.

He says the ECB's governing council asks itself "are we close to Japan? And the asnwer is no, we are not, for several reasons".

Those reasons are:

1) The ECB took decisive action at a very early stage

2) The condition of bank balance sheets is not as bad as in the 1990s in Japan..and the asset quality review will help to build confidence and clean up bad debts

3) Inflation expectations are still firmly anchored -- people believe that inflation will come back

2.25pm GMT

Draghi defends Germany

Draghi just defended Germany's large trade surplus, and criticised those who say its strong exports are hurting the eurozone.

Asked whether he agrees with US treasury Jack Lew that certain countries should do more to help their neighbours, Draghi cites a quote from Abraham Lincoln that you don't make the weak stronger by making the strong weaker.

I have never understood the idea that making Germany weaker would make other countries in the eurozone stronger, or that undermining the elements that made Europe great would help its weaker members, he added.

2.17pm GMT

Asked about the prospect of the ECB publishing its minutes, Draghi says the Bank wants to be even more transparent.

But not recklessly, so it is still reflecting on the issue.

 We must be the jealous guardians of the independence of our members, says Draghi, putting on his more serious face.

2.16pm GMT

The ECB has hardened its forward guidance precisely because the recovery is fragile, he adds.

2.12pm GMT

Draghi: Eurozone crisis is not over

Is the eurozone crisis over, given the recent recovery in the bonds of Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland, Greece....?

Draghi says NO.

It is premature to say this crisis is over, he says. Look at the unemployment figures -- more than 12% of adults are out of work.

The only good news is that the jobless rate has stopped rising in recent months, but it's too high.

There is, finally, an economic recovery, but it is weak and fragile. It is vulnerable to risks.

Updated at 2.16pm GMT

2.05pm GMT

How long can the ECB put up with inflation below 1%?

Draghi says that inflation will be on the low side of 2% for at least two years. We will act if we have reason to think the medium-term assessment has changed for the worse.

2.00pm GMT

On the drop in inflation in December, Draghi says it was generally expected, and partly due to technical changes in the German data. January's data won't be distorted, he adds.

1.59pm GMT

Claire Jones of the FT asks for more details on the instruments that the ECB could use -- could full-blown quantitative easing be used.

Draghi merely reiterates that the ECB has a range of options.

1.56pm GMT

The euro has fallen to a one-year low against the pound after Mario Draghi's comments this afternoon -- it's down 0.24% at 82.33p. 

Updated at 2.07pm GMT

1.54pm GMT

Here's the ECB statement

Mario Draghi's opening statement is online here:

Introductory statement to the press conference

And here's the section on forward guidance, in which the ECB hardened up its pledge to maintain accommodative monetary policy. The change is that this time, it uses the words "strongly" and "firmly":

Against this background, the Governing Council strongly emphasises that it will maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy for as long as necessary, which will assist the gradual economic recovery in the euro area.

Accordingly, we firmly reiterate our forward guidance that we continue to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time. As previously stated, this expectation is based on an overall subdued outlook for inflation extending into the medium term, given the broad-based weakness of the economy and subdued monetary dynamics.

With regard to money market conditions and their potential impact on our monetary policy stance, we are monitoring developments closely and are ready to consider all available instruments. Overall, we remain determined to maintain the high degree of monetary accommodation and to take further decisive action if required. 

(here's December's statement, for comparison)

1.51pm GMT

The WSJ wants details of the instruments which the ECB could use -- Draghi says that everything permitted by EU treaties is on the table. 

1.49pm GMT

Draghi: We've strengthened forward guidance

Onto questions: The ECB changed the wording of its comments about forward guidance on interest rates - have they hardened it up?

YES, Mario Draghi replies.

We have strengthened our forward guidance to address two issues, the signs of tightening in the short-term money markets, and the worsening inflation outlook in the medium term, he explains.

That's what our firmer language is addressing.

An ongoing tightening of money market rates or worsening of inflation outlook could force us to act, he added.

He adde that the ECB would consider "all possible instruments" to tackle these to contingencies .

Updated at 2.07pm GMT

1.44pm GMT

1.43pm GMT

Loan dynamics remain weak, Draghi adds, due to the business cycle, the task of balance sheet adjustment, and credit risks....

Updated at 1.43pm GMT

1.42pm GMT

Draghi: low inflation here for a while

On inflation (which fell last month). Draghi suggests that the risks are 'broadly balanced' (commodity prices could push it up; weak growth could push it down). Inflation will remain around current levels for the coming months, he says.

Francesco Papadia, a former ECB senior executive, says Draghi is warning the low inflation will remain for some time... 

1.40pm GMT

Recent economic indicators have suggested a gradual recovery is continuing in the euro area, says Mario Draghi.

There has also been an overall improvement in financial markets since summer 2012 (when Draghi dramatically changed the landscape by promising to do whatever it takes to defend the euro)

1.37pm GMT

The ECB stands ready to take "further decisive action" if needed, says Draghi:

1.36pm GMT

Draghi reiterates forward guidance

Mario Draghi reiterates the ECB's forward guidance, that it expects to maintain a high degree of accommodative monetary policy for some time - ie, rates will remain at their present or lower levels.

Updated at 1.37pm GMT

1.34pm GMT

Mario Draghi looks pretty upbeat as he reads out the ECB's statement.

He explains that the governing council left interest unchanged because the latest economic conditions back up its view of the state of the eurozone economy.

Underlying price pressures are expected to remain subdued.... monetary and credit dynamics remain subdued...inflation expectations are firmly anchored.

Such a constellation suggests we may experience a prolonged period of low inflation, before then rising towards the ECB's target of close to, but below 2%.

1.32pm GMT

And we're off -- Mario Draghi begins by welcoming Latvia to the eurozone (it joined at midnight on January 1st)

1.30pm GMT

ECB press conference - watch it live here

The European Central Bank press conference is about to start in Frankfurt - it's being streamed live here, and also on Bloomberg TV.

1.03pm GMT

And with the ECB sitting on its hands this month, Nomura economist Nick Matthews reckons president Mario Draghi will reiterate that it could act if needed, at this afternoon's press conference.

He said:

We expect President Draghi to continue to emphasise that the ECB is ready and able to act if required,"

We also expect the ECB to say there are a number of instruments available, though we do not expect them to single out any one at this stage.

Updated at 1.03pm GMT

1.00pm GMT

Carl Astorri, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, has welcomed the Bank of England's decision to leave rates unchanged:

“With unemployment still above the 7% threshold given by forward guidance, today’s decision by the Bank of England to maintain rates at 0.5% came as no surprise. However, it will not be long until the threshold is reached, so the MPC will soon have to reassess its approach to forward guidance, probably as early as next month’s Inflation Report. 
“Although the recovery is strengthening and unemployment is falling, it is still too soon to raise rates. There are only very tentative signs that the recovery is broadening out towards exports and business investment and the MPC will want to see both on a surer footing before it moves. And with inflation belatedly falling back, it has time to let this happen.” 

12.57pm GMT

ING economist Carsten Brzeski points out that the European Central Bank rarely changes monetary policy at its first meeting of the year:

Updated at 1.02pm GMT

12.48pm GMT

ECB leaves rates unchanged too

The European Central Bank has also voted to leave borrowing costs unchanged across the eurozone at their current record lows.

  • The headline rate remains at 0.25%
  • The deposit facility rate (what it pays banks on their deposits at the ECB) remains at 0.0%
  • The marginal lending rate (what banks pay to borrow overnight from the ECB) remains at 0.75% 

Mario Draghi, the ECB president, will give a press conference at 1.30pm GMT to explain the decision to the Frankfurt press pack.

(if you like the picture above - you'll love this: European Central Bank graffiti - in pictures)

Updated at 12.48pm GMT

12.36pm GMT

Next up, the European Central Bank's interest rate decision, in 9 minutes time....

12.35pm GMT

Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank reckons the Bank of England should quietly abandon its forward guidance on interest rates, having been caught out by the recovery in the UK unemployment market.

Wood writes:

The BoE seems to be leaving it until the February Inflation Report (12 February) to decide what to do with guidance.

It today left policy on hold and did not issue a statement. The BoE has sounded very dovish over the past few months.

But business surveys are booming and signal tightening capacity. Unemployment will likely fall to the 7.0% threshold in the next couple of months. When the BoE initially introduced guidance, less than six months ago, it saw only a 50% chance of unemployment reaching 7.0% by mid-2016. In our view, the BoE should now let forward guidance wither.

Changing the target to 6.5% would make "a mockery" of the whole process, he adds, concluding that UK interest rates will probably rise in around a year's time:

Wages are weak now, but the labour market is tightening fast and recruitment difficulties are showing up. A housing boom is forming, and the BoE’s credit rationing tools are unlikely to be able to control that forever. We expect the first rate hike in Q1 2015.

12.27pm GMT

BCC: Hold firm, Mr Carney

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), is worried that pressure is mounting on the Bank of England to raise rates earlier than it has indicated.

He has urged Governor Carney and crew to stick to their guns --that the UK economy is too weak to handle a rate rise. Wages are rising too slowly, and inflation is not a problem, Kern argues:

“While the decision to hold interest rates and QE was widely expected, it is concerning that there is increased clamour in the media and among some city analysts for an early increase in interest rates. We believe that the MPC’s forward guidance strategy continues to be beneficial for UK businesses. Although economic growth is stronger than most people envisaged a few months ago, there is still no evidence that the time is ripe to tighten policy, given that earnings are below 1% and inflation at just over 2%.

“Although the MPC has not issued an accompanying statement, it has said in the past that the 7% threshold is not a target and is unlikely to trigger early interest rate rises. Businesses are also concerned with inflation, so the MPC must remain committed to its 2% target. It is important to avoid premature steps that could snuff out the recovery before it is on firmer ground.”

Kern may be thinking of this well-argued piece in the FT by Chris Giles:

It is time for Carney to consider raising interest rates

In it, the FT's economics editor explains how Carney's forward guidance may be unravelling, given the surprising recovery in the jobless rate since it was introduced. Here's a flavour:

Carrying on regardless of the data is no way to run monetary policy. Instead, the BoE should be true to its word and undertake a thorough consideration of a rate rise alongside its quarterly forecasts in its February inflation report.

Updated at 12.28pm GMT

12.10pm GMT

Interest rate -- no change, no statement, no surprises

Today's highly predictable decision means UK interest rates have been pegged at the current record low of 0.5% since March 2009.

With the UK economy picking up, but unemployment still over Bank of England's 7% target, there was no chance of a rate rise today.

The only frisson of excitement was whether governor Mark Carney would issue a statement to either reiterate his forward guidance (no rate rise while the jobless rate is over 7%) or to tweak it (perhaps scrubbing out 7% and writing 6.5% instead)

He did neither. And that gave the pound a tiny lift (it's up 0.1% against the US dollar).

Attention is now turning to Frankfurt -- where the European Central Bank will announce its own decision on monetary policy at 12.45 GMT.

Updated at 12.11pm GMT

12.00pm GMT

UK interest rates unchanged

The Bank of England has left UK interest rates unchanged at 0.5%.

Its Monetary Policy Committee also voted not to launch any additional stimulus measures, leaving its QE programme unchanged at £375bn.

Not a surprise.

And there's no statement from the BoE either.

11.57am GMT

FastFT explains why Irish borrowing costs are now below the UK's: (see also our earlier post)

Ireland's successful debt sale earlier this year has reinforced the belief that it is firmly on the mend, pushing its bond yields lower and lower.

The UK's economic tidings are also markedly better, but that is leading investors to speculate that the Bank of England could raise interest rates as early as this year, and spurring many to pull money out of government bonds.

11.54am GMT

Heads-up.... nearly time for the Bank of England's monthly decision on monetary policy. The BoE isn't expected to make any changes to interest rates or its QE bond-buying programme, of course....

11.53am GMT

Irish borrowing costs fall below the UK's

One for the history books -- Ireland's borrowing costs have fallen below Britain's today, as the Republic continued to return to normality after its bailout programme.

It's now very slightly cheaper for Dublin to borrow for five years than for London, according to the price at which five-year bonds were changing hands today.

Quite a moment -- at a time when the borrowing costs of other eurozone countries has also fallen to much lower rates. 

For example, Spanish 10-year bonds are yielding just 3.7% -- have flirted with the 'danger zone' above 7% in the summer of 2012. 

The UK's equivalent 10-year bonds are yielding almost 3%.

Updated at 11.55am GMT

11.32am GMT

This latest record high in Greek unemployment is a slap in the face for the country's prime minister, argues crisis watcher Yiannis Mouzakis.

Antonis Samaras has insisted that the Greek economy will finally pull out of recession in 2014, but it's unclear whether that will deliver any balm to the labour market.

Data released yesterday showed that the eurozone jobless rate has been stuck at 12.1% since last spring, even though its economy has been growing ever since.

11.17am GMT

Greece's jobless rate jumped more sharply in October if you don't adjust for seasonal factors (ie the decline in tourism in October), as this graph shows:

Updated at 11.17am GMT

10.56am GMT

Greek unemployment at record high

Greece's unemployment agony has plumbed new depths, the day after Athens proudly took on the EU presidency amid much talk about how the eurozone crisis was easing.

Elstat has announced that the Greek unemployment rate climbed to 27.8% on a seasonally adjusted basis in October 2013. September's rate has also been revised higher, to 27.7% (from 27.4%).

In October there 3,597,779 people in work,1,387,520 out of work, and a further 3,360,513 classed as inactive.

Greece's long-running austerity programme has driven unemployment across the country soaring -- up by 200% since the financial crisis began, as this chart shows:

The youth unemployment rate remains particularly awful - it's now 57.9%, up from 56% a year ago.

With Greece's industrial production falling by 6.1% in November, there's no sign in today's data that the much-heralded Greek recovery has kicked off.

10.23am GMT

Today's EC economic sentiment data (see here) also shows that confidence is returning to the weaker parts of the eurozone, flags up Frederik Ducrozet of Credit Agricole:

All the data's here, by the way.

Updated at 10.27am GMT

10.20am GMT

My colleague Sarah Butler has analysed Tesco's unimpressive Christmas trading figures - here's her story:

Tesco admitted on Thursday that its profits would come in as much as £150m below expectations set down only last month after a tough end to the year for mainstream grocery retailers.

Britain's biggest supermarket chain revealed a worse than expected 2.4% fall in sales excluding petrol at stores open for more than a year in the six weeks to 4 January. Underlying sales continued to fall in all Tesco's major overseas markets, contributing to a fall of 2.8% in like-for-like sales for the group over the period. Analysts had expected sales to fall by up to 2%.

Tesco warns profits will be lower than expected as Christmas sales disappoint

10.16am GMT

Cass professor: Retailers made four big blunders

Back to this morning's Christmas turkeys rading figures.

Andre Spicer, Professor of Organisational Behaviour at Cass Business School, has criticised the likes of M&S, Tesco and Morrisons for making four big mistakes.

He says they are guilty of copying the competition, ignoring basic consumer psychology, resting on their laurels and not making enough of their retail foot print.

 Spicer writes:

The big retailers which announced disappointing results today find themselves caught in a disappearing middle – between higher end retailers like John Lewis and discounters like Aldi. They have largely reacted by trying to copy the competition – for instance discounting products because others have, or offering product lines which don’t match their core image.

They have also ignored basic consumer psychology by discounting in the lead up to Christmas. One of the basic rules of consumer behaviour is that people are willing to pay far more before Christmas than afterwards. This is partially due to what psychologists call hyperbolic discounting – the willingness to pay more now than to have to wait and pay less later. By copying competitors and discounting too quickly, the retailers were not able to take advantage of this very profitable quirk of consumer psychology.

The big companies have been resting on their laurels. This means while they are trying to change things around the fringe, they may have overlooked the reason that customers go to them in the first place – for good value in the case of Tesco or for quality in the case of M&S.

Finally, these retailers have not made enough out of their large chain of stores. Successful retailers like John Lewis use their stores not just as a space to shift goods, but as a place which communicates their core messages and reinforces their values. This means consumers can go there for information and to look at goods, and then order online. In contrast, going into the average Tesco is a depressing experience most people avoid if they can.

Updated at 10.17am GMT

10.16am GMT

10.10am GMT

Eurozone economic confidence rises

Is Europe turning the corner?

fields.bodyText: And that's all until the morning. A reminder of the key points: • European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi has warned that the eurozone crisis not over, given the weak recovery and record unemployment levels. Faced with weak inflation, the ECB strengthened its forward guidance, promising "firmly" to keep monetary policy accommodative for as long as needed. At a sometimes light-hearted press conference, Draghi also warned that inflation will remain below target for at least the next two years and promised to take further action if needed to stimulate the economy. See 3.15pm for a full round-up. • Earlier the ECB, and the Bank of England, had both decided to leave interest rates unchanged and also not launch any fresh stimulus programmes. • Some economists believe the BoE will soon have to raise rates, but business leaders say it should stick to its position that the UK economy is too weak. • Over in France, the audit office head has warned that its national debt is at danger levels • While in the UK, Morrisons and Tesco have emerged as clear losers from the Christmas trading period. Marks & Spencer reported that clothing sales had tumbled again, but got a better reception from the City. There's a round-up here. while full coverage of how the news broke at 7am starts here, and there's an explanation of what went wrong here. • Greece's unemployment rate hit a new record high. • Ireland's borrowing costs have fallen below the UK's Goodnight, and thanks for the comments (as ever!). GW European stock markets have closed, and the big three indices all ended in the red. In Britain, Morrisons dragged the FTSE 100 index down, while the French market was hit by the warning over its national debt levels (see previous post). FTSE 100: down 30 points at 6691, -0.45% German DAX: down 76 points at 9421, -0.8% French CAC: down 35 points at 4225, -0.8% Spanish IBEX: down 19 points at 10234, - 0.19% Italian FTSE MIB: up 66 points at 19503, +0.34% David Madden, market analyst at IG, says Mario Draghi's more serious comments also hit optimism in the City: Equities drifted lower as Mario Draghi fails to convince the market that he can save the eurozone from sinking into the abyss..... Mr Draghi tried to reassure the market he has a few cards up his sleeve, but actions speak louder than words. And we didn't get much action today. The head of France's national audit office has added to the growing pressure on Francois Hollande by warning that the country's debt levels are approaching the danger zone. Didier Migaud said in a speech that the French national debt hit 93.4% of GDP, warning: "The level that's been reached has put our country in a danger zone. "Efforts undertaken so far are not sufficient to get out." Migaud, president of the independent Cour des Comptes body, also warned that France will face higher borrowing costs when the economic recovery picks up. Reuters has the full story: France's national debt stood at 90.2 percent of GDP at the end of 2012. The government expects the debt burden to peak this year at 95.1 percent of GDP. "What wasn't done in 2011, 2012 and 2013 only adds to the extra distance that will have to be travelled in the coming years," Migaud said. "This extra distance won't be the least demanding - quite the contrary." Despite the growing debt mountain, French bonds, which are among the most liquid in the world, have found firm demand from investors seeking richer yields than those offered on their low-risk German equivalents.Yet even though France benefits from low borrowing costs, servicing France's debt costs the state about €50bn ($68bn) annually, equivalent to about 2.5% of national output. Migaud said a one percentage point increase in interest rates would add 2 billion euros to the state's debt service costs in the first year and €15bn in the tenth year afterwards. Despite record levels of debt, France enjoyed its lowest borrowing costs on record last year with an average interest rate of only 1.54% on its medium and long-term debt issued in 2013. In its first bond auction of the year, France sold €8.3bn of long-term debt on Thursday, drawing strong investor demand. President Francois Hollande's Socialist government plans to make savings of €15bn this year with €9bn coming from the central state and 6 billion euros from the social security system. Migaud said that the priority should be on making savings in social services, describing France as unique among European countries for the deficits its social welfare system has consistently run over the last 20 years. Worth noting that economists disagree about what stage a national debt becomes unsustainable, especially after errors were found in the well-known research paper by Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff. We started the day with unexpectedly bad news from Morrisons, weak sales from Tesco and another quarter of falling clothing sales at M&S. The day ends with Morrisons leading the FTSE 100 fallers (down almost 8%), M&S topping the risers (+3%) and Tesco down around 1.2%. Michael Hewson of CMC Markets sums up the day: The opportunism of Morrisons in trying to slip out its bad news at the same time as Tesco and M&S appears to have backfired spectacularly as its shares got pummelled lower to levels last seen in October 2008. Like for like sales slid 5.6% in the 6 weeks to January and highlighted the catching up this particular food retailer has to do in catching up its peers in the on-line space as well as the smaller convenience stores that seem to be appearing with increasing regularity on our high streets from Tesco and Sainsbury. A price downgrade from Panmure Gordon hasn’t helped its cause either. Marks and Spencer’s food offering has once again come to its rescue, while its general merchandising operation once again showed a fall in like for like sales, the tenth quarter in a row we’ve seen a decline here. While CEO Mr Bolland appears to have the confidence of a lot of the major shareholders for now, the fact that we are almost three years in to the company’s turnaround plan will raise some major concerns from other shareholders who don’t seem to see any silver lining on this side of the business. Nevertheless the shares have rebounded to the top of the FTSE100 on relief that the numbers weren’t as bad as was feared initially after the heavy discounting seen in the pre-Christmas trading period, and an upgrade to “buy” from Investec. Tesco continues to get squeezed from above and below by smaller peers like Waitrose and Marks and Spencer in the premier part of the food space, while also feeling the effects from the budget side in the form of Lidl and Aldi. The problem being the number one grocer in the UK is that you find that you have to run that little bit faster simply to stand still and for now it is even struggling to do that, particularly at a time when consumers are much more cash conscious. Back in the City, the FTSE 100 is on track to close at its lowest level of the year. It's down 31 points, or 0.5%, in late trading, dragged down by Morrison (-8% after its mini profit warning this morning). ING's Carsten Brzeski says that the European Central Bank has " stepped up its verbal power, stressing its determination to act again" at today's press conference. He also explains the different stimulus measures which the ECB could take: In our view, it looks as if the ECB is trying to build a tailor-made toolbox with different tools for different situations. In our view, there are three main triggers for further ECB action in the coming months: i) unwarranted money market tightening; ii) a faltering of the recovery; and iii) a stronger euro exchange rate. Obviously, these three factors would have a deflationary impact on the Eurozone economy. Tackling these three problems would indeed require different instruments: (conditional) liquidity for the money market, funding for lending and/or QE for the economy and a negative deposit rate for the exchange rate (or a combination of all three). Well, that was entertaining. European Central Bank watchers sometimes joke about whether good Good Mario or Bad Mario will turn up to the monthly press conference. Occasionally we get Super Mario - notably after the ECB single-handedly calmed the eurozone crisis with his OMT bond-buying programme. Today we were treated to Merry Mario, joking about the difference between perverse and perverted, and happily declaring that the ECB can't run out of money. But beyond the levity, the message from the ECB is that inflation is going to lurk below its 2% target for at least the next two years. That's why the central bank has "firmly" reiterated its pledge to keep accommodative monetary policies for some time. Here's the new guidance (emphasis mine): Against this background, the Governing Council strongly emphasises that it will maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy for as long as necessary, which will assist the gradual economic recovery in the euro area. Accordingly, we firmly reiterate our forward guidance that we continue to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time. The other key points are Draghi's warning that the eurozone crisis is not over. Here's the key quote: "I'd be very cautious about saying that, be very, very cautious... The recovery is there but it's weak, it's modest and as I said many times, it's fragile meaning that there are several risks from financial to economic to geopolitical to political risks that could undermine easily this recovery." And on the weak recovery, he warned: "The risks surrounding the economic outlook for the euro area continue to be on the downside. Developments in global money and financial market conditions and related uncertainties may have the potential to negatively affect economic conditions." Other interesting points were Draghi's defence of Germany's trade surplus, arguing that attempting to rein in its exports would not help the rest of Europe. And his insistence that Europe is not repeating the mistakes that drove Japan into a deflationary spiral. But while Mario Draghi repeatedly said the ECB was ready to act, he didn't really explain what it might do. And finally, a question about whether any governing council members voted for an interest rate cut today. Draghi replies that the discussions focused on potential risks to the recovery. Back to serious stuff, with a question about the Asset Quality Review. Draghi says that these important new stress tests will treat eurozone government debt as risk-free -- as laid out under the Basel rules. There has been talk that the ECB is worried about those banks who have gorged themselves on their own sovereign debt. More levity in Frankfurt, after Mario Draghi is asked about his comments last month that Germans have a perverse fear of inflation. Draghi turns to dictionary corner, joking that "there is a difference between perverse and perverted" (take note, younger readers) Perverse, he says means "persistent in error, different from what is reasonable". And Draghi adds that he understands the concerns of savers and hopes they will share in the economic recovery which the ECB is striving for. A journalist asks whether the ECB can ever run out of money. Draghi gives a little chortle, and says that "technically, no....we cannot run out of money". So we have ample resources for coping with all our emergencies. Draghi insists that Europe is not plunging into a Japanese-style deflation crisis. He says the ECB's governing council asks itself "are we close to Japan? And the asnwer is no, we are not, for several reasons". Those reasons are: 1) The ECB took decisive action at a very early stage 2) The condition of bank balance sheets is not as bad as in the 1990s in Japan..and the asset quality review will help to build confidence and clean up bad debts 3) Inflation expectations are still firmly anchored -- people believe that inflation will come back Draghi just defended Germany's large trade surplus, and criticised those who say its strong exports are hurting the eurozone. Asked whether he agrees with US treasury Jack Lew that certain countries should do more to help their neighbours, Draghi cites a quote from Abraham Lincoln that you don't make the weak stronger by making the strong weaker. I have never understood the idea that making Germany weaker would make other countries in the eurozone stronger, or that undermining the elements that made Europe great would help its weaker members, he added. Asked about the prospect of the ECB publishing its minutes, Draghi says the Bank wants to be even more transparent. But not recklessly, so it is still reflecting on the issue. We must be the jealous guardians of the independence of our members, says Draghi, putting on his more serious face. The ECB has hardened its forward guidance precisely because the recovery is fragile, he adds. Is the eurozone crisis over, given the recent recovery in the bonds of Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland, Greece....? Draghi says NO. It is premature to say this crisis is over, he says. Look at the unemployment figures -- more than 12% of adults are out of work. The only good news is that the jobless rate has stopped rising in recent months, but it's too high. There is, finally, an economic recovery, but it is weak and fragile. It is vulnerable to risks. How long can the ECB put up with inflation below 1%? Draghi says that inflation will be on the low side of 2% for at least two years. We will act if we have reason to think the medium-term assessment has changed for the worse. On the drop in inflation in December, Draghi says it was generally expected, and partly due to technical changes in the German data. January's data won't be distorted, he adds. Claire Jones of the FT asks for more details on the instruments that the ECB could use -- could full-blown quantitative easing be used. Draghi merely reiterates that the ECB has a range of options. The euro has fallen to a one-year low against the pound after Mario Draghi's comments this afternoon -- it's down 0.24% at 82.33p. Mario Draghi's opening statement is online here: Introductory statement to the press conference And here's the section on forward guidance, in which the ECB hardened up its pledge to maintain accommodative monetary policy. The change is that this time, it uses the words "strongly" and "firmly": Against this background, the Governing Council strongly emphasises that it will maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy for as long as necessary, which will assist the gradual economic recovery in the euro area. Accordingly, we firmly reiterate our forward guidance that we continue to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time. As previously stated, this expectation is based on an overall subdued outlook for inflation extending into the medium term, given the broad-based weakness of the economy and subdued monetary dynamics. With regard to money market conditions and their potential impact on our monetary policy stance, we are monitoring developments closely and are ready to consider all available instruments. Overall, we remain determined to maintain the high degree of monetary accommodation and to take further decisive action if required. (here's December's statement, for comparison) The WSJ wants details of the instruments which the ECB could use -- Draghi says that everything permitted by EU treaties is on the table. Onto questions: The ECB changed the wording of its comments about forward guidance on interest rates - have they hardened it up? YES, Mario Draghi replies. We have strengthened our forward guidance to address two issues, the signs of tightening in the short-term money markets, and the worsening inflation outlook in the medium term, he explains. That's what our firmer language is addressing. An ongoing tightening of money market rates or worsening of inflation outlook could force us to act, he added. He adde that the ECB would consider "all possible instruments" to tackle these to contingencies . Loan dynamics remain weak, Draghi adds, due to the business cycle, the task of balance sheet adjustment, and credit risks.... On inflation (which fell last month). Draghi suggests that the risks are 'broadly balanced' (commodity prices could push it up; weak growth could push it down). Inflation will remain around current levels for the coming months, he says. Francesco Papadia, a former ECB senior executive, says Draghi is warning the low inflation will remain for some time... Recent economic indicators have suggested a gradual recovery is continuing in the euro area, says Mario Draghi. There has also been an overall improvement in financial markets since summer 2012 (when Draghi dramatically changed the landscape by promising to do whatever it takes to defend the euro) The ECB stands ready to take "further decisive action" if needed, says Draghi: Mario Draghi reiterates the ECB's forward guidance, that it expects to maintain a high degree of accommodative monetary policy for some time - ie, rates will remain at their present or lower levels. Mario Draghi looks pretty upbeat as he reads out the ECB's statement. He explains that the governing council left interest unchanged because the latest economic conditions back up its view of the state of the eurozone economy. Underlying price pressures are expected to remain subdued.... monetary and credit dynamics remain subdued...inflation expectations are firmly anchored. Such a constellation suggests we may experience a prolonged period of low inflation, before then rising towards the ECB's target of close to, but below 2%. And we're off -- Mario Draghi begins by welcoming Latvia to the eurozone (it joined at midnight on January 1st) The European Central Bank press conference is about to start in Frankfurt - it's being streamed live here, and also on Bloomberg TV. And with the ECB sitting on its hands this month, Nomura economist Nick Matthews reckons president Mario Draghi will reiterate that it could act if needed, at this afternoon's press conference. He said: We expect President Draghi to continue to emphasise that the ECB is ready and able to act if required," We also expect the ECB to say there are a number of instruments available, though we do not expect them to single out any one at this stage. Carl Astorri, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, has welcomed the Bank of England's decision to leave rates unchanged: “With unemployment still above the 7% threshold given by forward guidance, today’s decision by the Bank of England to maintain rates at 0.5% came as no surprise. However, it will not be long until the threshold is reached, so the MPC will soon have to reassess its approach to forward guidance, probably as early as next month’s Inflation Report. “Although the recovery is strengthening and unemployment is falling, it is still too soon to raise rates. There are only very tentative signs that the recovery is broadening out towards exports and business investment and the MPC will want to see both on a surer footing before it moves. And with inflation belatedly falling back, it has time to let this happen.” ING economist Carsten Brzeski points out that the European Central Bank rarely changes monetary policy at its first meeting of the year: The European Central Bank has also voted to leave borrowing costs unchanged across the eurozone at their current record lows. The headline rate remains at 0.25% The deposit facility rate (what it pays banks on their deposits at the ECB) remains at 0.0% The marginal lending rate (what banks pay to borrow overnight from the ECB) remains at 0.75% Mario Draghi, the ECB president, will give a press conference at 1.30pm GMT to explain the decision to the Frankfurt press pack. (if you like the picture above - you'll love this: European Central Bank graffiti - in pictures) Next up, the European Central Bank's interest rate decision, in 9 minutes time.... Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank reckons the Bank of England should quietly abandon its forward guidance on interest rates, having been caught out by the recovery in the UK unemployment market. Wood writes: The BoE seems to be leaving it until the February Inflation Report (12 February) to decide what to do with guidance. It today left policy on hold and did not issue a statement. The BoE has sounded very dovish over the past few months. But business surveys are booming and signal tightening capacity. Unemployment will likely fall to the 7.0% threshold in the next couple of months. When the BoE initially introduced guidance, less than six months ago, it saw only a 50% chance of unemployment reaching 7.0% by mid-2016. In our view, the BoE should now let forward guidance wither. Changing the target to 6.5% would make "a mockery" of the whole process, he adds, concluding that UK interest rates will probably rise in around a year's time: Wages are weak now, but the labour market is tightening fast and recruitment difficulties are showing up. A housing boom is forming, and the BoE’s credit rationing tools are unlikely to be able to control that forever. We expect the first rate hike in Q1 2015. David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), is worried that pressure is mounting on the Bank of England to raise rates earlier than it has indicated. He has urged Governor Carney and crew to stick to their guns --that the UK economy is too weak to handle a rate rise. Wages are rising too slowly, and inflation is not a problem, Kern argues: “While the decision to hold interest rates and QE was widely expected, it is concerning that there is increased clamour in the media and among some city analysts for an early increase in interest rates. We believe that the MPC’s forward guidance strategy continues to be beneficial for UK businesses. Although economic growth is stronger than most people envisaged a few months ago, there is still no evidence that the time is ripe to tighten policy, given that earnings are below 1% and inflation at just over 2%. “Although the MPC has not issued an accompanying statement, it has said in the past that the 7% threshold is not a target and is unlikely to trigger early interest rate rises. Businesses are also concerned with inflation, so the MPC must remain committed to its 2% target. It is important to avoid premature steps that could snuff out the recovery before it is on firmer ground.” Kern may be thinking of this well-argued piece in the FT by Chris Giles: It is time for Carney to consider raising interest rates In it, the FT's economics editor explains how Carney's forward guidance may be unravelling, given the surprising recovery in the jobless rate since it was introduced. Here's a flavour: Carrying on regardless of the data is no way to run monetary policy. Instead, the BoE should be true to its word and undertake a thorough consideration of a rate rise alongside its quarterly forecasts in its February inflation report. Today's highly predictable decision means UK interest rates have been pegged at the current record low of 0.5% since March 2009. With the UK economy picking up, but unemployment still over Bank of England's 7% target, there was no chance of a rate rise today. The only frisson of excitement was whether governor Mark Carney would issue a statement to either reiterate his forward guidance (no rate rise while the jobless rate is over 7%) or to tweak it (perhaps scrubbing out 7% and writing 6.5% instead) He did neither. And that gave the pound a tiny lift (it's up 0.1% against the US dollar). Attention is now turning to Frankfurt -- where the European Central Bank will announce its own decision on monetary policy at 12.45 GMT. The Bank of England has left UK interest rates unchanged at 0.5%. webTitle: Nuclear Decommissioning Authority axes commercial director role

fields.standfirst: Sean Balmer exits post after eight years following heavy criticism of organisation's performance, particularly at Sellafield
fields.body:
The role of commercial director of the much criticised public body overseeing the cleanup of Britain's old nuclear power stations has been axed amid a wider management shakeup.

The exit of Sean Balmer, who has been at the Nuclear Decommissioning Authority for eight years, follows recent heavy criticism of the organisation's performance, particularly at Sellafield in Cumbria.

John Clarke, the chief executive of the NDA, has scrapped the commercial director post and created three new positions on his executive team including one full-time job looking after Sellafield, the UK's largest atomic complex.

The moves also follow the departure of the chief operating officer, Mark Lesinski, before Christmas and the planned exit at the end of March of the head of human resources, Jim McLaughlin.

Clarke was subjected to ferocious criticism from politicians at a meeting of the Commons public accounts committee that expressed grave concerns over the estimated £70bn cost to the taxpayer of work at Sellafield.

The NDA boss appeared at before the committee alongside Tom Zarges, the boss of the NDA's private sector contractor Nuclear Management Partners (NMP) which has just been controversially reappointed to clean up Sellafield.

Clarke insisted that the reappointment was the best way forward even though he admitted NMP had repeatedly failed to meet many of its targets, while Zarges said he was "humbled and truly sorry" for cost overruns and an expenses scandal.

Clarke said the latest management changes would improve the performance of his organisation. "It was always the case that the role of the NDA would change as the private sector takes a greater role in delivering our mission and it's important that the make-up of our executive team reflects that," he said.

"I'm confident that these changes will place us in good shape to face the challenges that lie ahead as we strive to accelerate the cleanup of the UK's nuclear legacy while delivering value for money for the taxpayer," he added.

Clarke said that Peter Lutwyche, from Jacobs Engineering, would take on the Sellafield director role while David Vineall, from Tata Steel, would take over from McLaughlin in the spring.

The NDA employs only 300 staff directly but is responsible for overseeing annual spending of over £2bn on cleaning up the sites where nuclear power stations have ceased operation having come to the end of their working lives.

The Sellafield facility, first used by the ministry of defence for making atom bombs, also includes Calder Hall which was Britain's first nuclear power plant, the THORP atomic fuel reprocessing plant and the Magnox nuclear fuel reprocessing plant.
